children: Flux.ones(size...) is deprecated, please use Flux.ones32(size...) or Base.ones(Float32, size...)
Flux.zeros(size...) is deprecated, please use Flux.zeros32(size...) or Base.zeros(Float32, size...)
Flux.ones32 is always Float32, use Base.ones to specify the element type
Flux.zeros32 is always Float32, use Base.zeros to specify the element type
# This had an explicit @adjoint rule, calling Zygote.∇map(__context__, f, args...), until v0.12
Broadcasting is not safe to use with RNNs, as it does not guarantee an iteration order.
Re-writing this as a comprehension would be better.
# map isn't really safe either, but
Flux.Zeros is no more, has ceased to be, is bereft of life, is an ex-boondoggle... please use bias=false instead
was used both Dense(10, 2, initb = Zeros) and Dense(rand(2,10), Zeros())
`Flux.Optimise.update!(x, x̄)` was not used internally and has been removed. Please write `x .-= x̄` instead.
Flux.Diagonal is now Flux.Scale, and also allows an activation function.
Flux.Diagonal is now Flux.Scale, and also allows an activation function.
Deprecate this eventually once saving models w/o structure is no more
loadparams! will be deprecated eventually. Use loadmodel! instead.
Channel notation: Changed to match Conv, but very softly deprecated! Perhaps change to
for v0.14, but there is no plan to remove these.
Remove sub-module Data, while making sure Flux.Data.DataLoader keeps working
Sub-module Flux.Data has been removed. The only thing it contained may be accessed as Flux.DataLoader
Valid method in Optimise, old implicit style, is:
Valid methods in Train, new explict style, are:
train!(loss, model, data, opt)  # preferred train!(loss, model, data, opt::Optimisers.AbstractRule)  # if you forget setup
Provide friendly errors for what happens if you mix these up:
can't mix implict Params with explict state!
To use `Flux.params(m)` in `train!`, the 4th argument must be from the old `Flux.Optimise` sub-module.
But better to use the new explicit style, in which `m` itself is the 2nd argument.
can't mix implict Params with explict rule from Optimisers.jl
To use `Flux.params(m)` in `train!`, the 4th argument must be from the old `Flux.Optimise` sub-module.
But better to use the new explicit style, in which `m` itself is the 2nd argument.
lets you use new name with implicit params too.
called omega, and there are more fields
called delta now, and struct name differs
Flux.setup does not know how to translate this old-style implicit rule to a new-style Optimisers.jl explicit rule
should be called in a loop, it makes less sense to call
for you if you forgot. But let's make sure that such uses give a helpful error:
# This error method requires narrowing the main worker method of Flux.Optimise
# to accept only arrays. Remove if this causes problems!
* For the implicit style, this needs `update(::AbstractOptimiser, ::Params, ::Grads)`
* For the explicit style, `update(state, model, grad)` needs `state = Flux.setup(opt, model)`.
An easy error to make is to pass result of explicit gradient(...), not gradient(...)[1] Can't catch every case, but can catch many simple Flux models:
# Zygote will make a NamedTuple{(:layers,)} for the gradient of Chain, Diffractor a Tangent
explicit `update!(opt, model, grad)` wants the gradient for the model alone,
not the whole tuple from `gradient(m -> loss(m, x, y), model)`. You probably want `grads[1]`.
# calls error case "Invalid input" just above
One more easy error to catch is using explicit gradient with
can't mix implicit Params with explicit gradients!
* For the implicit style, this needs `update(::AbstractOptimiser, ::Params, ::Grads)` with implicit gradient.
* For the explicit style, `update(state, model, grad)` needs the model itself, and `state = Flux.setup(opt, model)`.
v0.14 deprecations Enable these when 0.14 is released, and delete const ClipGrad = Optimise.ClipValue etc: Base.
ClipValue ClipGrad train!(loss::Function, ps::Zygote.Params, data, opt) = throw(ArgumentError( """On Flux 0.14,
opt = Flux.setup(Adam(), model); train!(loss_mxy, model, data, opt)
accepts the model as its first argument. """ ))
